info.name: Library
info.description: This project demonstrates a RESTful API built with **Node.js** and **JSON Server**. It includes endpoints for **Books**, **Households**, **Users**, and **Wishlists**, supporting full CRUD operations: **Create**, **Read**, **Update**, and **Delete**

item.name: 1- Books

request.description:
### Retrieve all books

This endpoint makes an HTTP GET request to retrieve all books.

#### Response

The response for this request is a JSON array with the following schema:

``` json
[
  {
    "id": "number",
    "title": "string",
    "author": "string",
    "publicationDate": "string",
    "isbn": "string",
    "createdAt": "string",
    "updatedAt": "string",
    "releaseDate": "string"
  }
]

 ```

request.description:
### Update Book Details

#### Description

This endpoint is used to update the details of a book by its ID.

#### Request Body

- title (string, required): The title of the book.
    
- author (string, required): The author of the book.
    
- isbn (string, required): The ISBN of the book.
    
- releaseDate (string, required): The release date of the book.
    

#### Response Body (JSON Schema)

``` json
{
  "type": "object",
  "properties": {
    "title": {"type": "string"},
    "author": {"type": "string"},
    "isbn": {"type": "string"},
    "releaseDate": {"type": "string"},
    "createdAt": {"type": "string"},
    "updatedAt": {"type": "string"},
    "id": {"type": "integer"}
  }
}

 ```

request.description:
### Delete Book

Deletes a book by its ID.

#### Request Body

This request does not require a request body.

#### Response

This request returns a success status code if the book is deleted successfully.

item.description:
###  **Purpose**:

This folder represents the main resource for storing book information in the system. It acts as a central reference used in users wishlists and for display or management purposes.

###  **Data Structure**:

Each `book` object typically contains:

- `id` (number): Unique identifier.
    
- `title` (string): Book title.
    
- `author` (string): Authors full name.
    
- `isbn` (string): Book's International Standard Book Number.
    
- `releaseDate` (string | ISO format): Date the book was released.
    
- `createdAt` / `updatedAt`: Timestamps for audit.
    

###  **Relationships**:

- Linked in `wishlists.books[]` via ID references.
    
- Not directly associated with users or households but appears through wishlists.
    

###  **Special Notes**:

- Books are referenced by ID, not embedded.
    
- Must be created before they can be added to wishlists.

request.description:
### Retrieve Household by ID

This endpoint makes an HTTP GET request to retrieve a household by its ID.

#### Request

- URL: `{{baseURL}}households/:housdeholdid`
    
- Method: `GET`
    

#### Response

The response will include the following fields:

- `name` (string): The name of the household.
    
- `createdAt` (string): The timestamp when the household was created.
    
- `updatedAt` (string): The timestamp when the household was last updated.
    
- `id` (integer): The unique identifier of the household.

request.description:
### Delete Household

Deletes a household by its ID.

#### HTTP Request

DELETE {{baseURL}}/households/:householdid

#### Response

The response for this request is a JSON schema.

item.description:
###  **Purpose**:

The `households` folder groups users under shared family or organizational units. It's useful for filtering or aggregating data (like total wishlist books per household).

###  **Data Structure**:

Each household contains:

- `id` (number): Unique identifier.
    
- `name` (string): The name of the household.
    
- `createdAt`, `updatedAt`: Timestamps.
    
- `links`: Contains a self-link to fetch detailed info.
    

###  **Relationships**:

- A `user.householdId` points to a household.
    
- Used in grouped analytics like "wishlist books per household."
    

###  **Special Notes**:

- Deleting a household does not automatically delete its users.
    
- Aggregation endpoints (e.g., `/households/:id/wishlistBooks`) compute derived data.

request.description:
### Retrieve All Users

This endpoint makes an HTTP GET request to retrieve all users.

#### Request Body

This request does not require a request body.

#### Response Body

The response will contain an array of user objects, where each user object includes the following fields:

- `email` (string): The email address of the user.
    
- `firstName` (string): The first name of the user.
    
- `lastName` (string): The last name of the user.
    
- `householdId` (integer): The ID of the household to which the user belongs.
    
- `createdAt` (string): The timestamp indicating when the user was created.
    
- `updatedAt` (string): The timestamp indicating when the user was last updated.
    
- `wishlistId` (integer): The ID of the user's wishlist.
    
- `id` (integer): The unique ID of the user.
    
- `links` (array): An array of objects containing links related to the user, where each object includes the following fields:
    
    - `rel` (string): The relationship of the link.
        
    - `href` (string): The URL of the link.
        

An example response body for this request is:

``` json
[
    {
        "email": "",
        "firstName": "",
        "lastName": "",
        "householdId": 0,
        "createdAt": "",
        "updatedAt": "",
        "wishlistId": 0,
        "id": 0,
        "links": [
            {
                "rel": "",
                "href": ""
            }
        ]
    }
]

 ```

request.description:
### Update User Details

The `PUT` request is used to update a user by specifying the `UserID` in the endpoint URL.

#### Request Body

The request body should be in raw format and should include the following parameters:

- `firstName` (string): The first name of the user.
    
- `lastName` (string): The last name of the user.
    
- `email` (string): The email address of the user.
    

#### Example Request

```
{
  "firstName": "John",
  "lastName": "Doe",
  "email": "johndoe@example.com"
}

 ```

#### Response (JSON Schema)

``` json
{
  "type": "object",
  "properties": {
    "firstName": {"type": "string"},
    "lastName": {"type": "string"},
    "email": {"type": "string"},
    "createdAt": {"type": "string"},
    "updatedAt": {"type": "string"},
    "id": {"type": "integer"}
  }
}

 ```

request.description:
### Delete User by ID

#### Request

- Method: DELETE
    
- Endpoint: `{{baseURL}}users/:UserID`
    

#### Request Body

This request does not require a request body.

#### Response

The response for this request is a JSON schema with the following properties:

- `message`: A string indicating the result of the deletion operation.
    
- `deletedUserID`: A string representing the ID of the deleted user.
    

Example response:

``` json
{
    "message": "User deleted successfully",
    "deletedUserID": "12345"
}

 ```

item.description:
###  **Purpose**:

The `users` folder holds all end-user profiles who can own wishlists and belong to households. Each user is a central actor in the system.

###  **Data Structure**:

User objects include:

- `id`: Unique ID.
    
- `firstName`, `lastName`: User name fields.
    
- `email`: Email address (used as a key in some apps).
    
- `householdId`: ID reference to the `households` table.
    
- `wishlistId`: ID reference to a user's wishlist.
    
- `createdAt`, `updatedAt`: Metadata timestamps.
    
- `links`: Includes self-referencing link.
    

###  **Relationships**:

- Belongs to one `household`.
    
- Owns one `wishlist`.
    

###  **Special Notes**:

- On creation, a new wishlist is also created and linked.
    
- Users may share a household but have unique wishlists.

item.name: 4- Wishlists

request.description:
### Retrieve All Wishlists

This endpoint makes an HTTP GET request to retrieve all wishlists.

#### Request Body

This request does not require a request body.

#### Response

The response will include an array of wishlists, where each wishlist object contains the following keys:

- `name`: The name of the wishlist (string)
    
- `books`: An array of book IDs included in the wishlist
    
- `id`: The unique identifier of the wishlist (integer)
    

Example response:

``` json
[{"name":"","books":[0],"id":0}]

 ```

request.description:
### Create New Wishlist

This endpoint is used to create a new wishlist.

#### Request Body

- Type: Raw
    
- Description: JSON payload with the following parameters:
    
    - `name` (string): The name of the wishlist.
        
    - `books` (array): An array of books in the wishlist.
        

Example:

``` json
{
  "name": "{{$randomFullName}}",
  "books": []
}

 ```

#### Response

- `name` (string): The name of the wishlist.
    
- `books` (array): An array of books in the wishlist.
    
- `createdAt` (string): The timestamp of when the wishlist was created.
    
- `updatedAt` (string): The timestamp of when the wishlist was last updated.
    
- `id` (number): The unique identifier of the wishlist.
    

Example:

``` json
{
  "name": "",
  "books": [],
  "createdAt": "",
  "updatedAt": "",
  "id": 0
}

 ```

request.description:
### Update Wishlist

This endpoint is used to update a wishlist by its ID.

#### Request Body

- `name` (string, required): The name of the wishlist.
    
- `books` (array, required): An array of book IDs.
    

#### Response

The response will be a JSON object with the following properties:

- `name` (string): The name of the wishlist.
    
- `books` (array): An array of book IDs associated with the wishlist.
    
- `createdAt` (string): The timestamp of when the wishlist was created.
    
- `updatedAt` (string): The timestamp of when the wishlist was last updated.
    
- `id` (number): The ID of the wishlist.
    

#### Example Request

``` json
{
  "name": "examplewishlist",
  "books": [1, 2, 3]
}

 ```

#### Example Response

``` json
{
  "name": "updatedwishlist",
  "books": [1, 2, 3],
  "createdAt": "2022-01-01T12:00:00Z",
  "updatedAt": "2022-01-02T08:00:00Z",
  "id": 123
}

 ```

request.description:
### Delete Wishlist

This endpoint is used to delete a wishlist by its ID.

#### Request Body

This request does not require a request body.

#### Response

The response will not contain a response body. The status code will indicate the success or failure of the deletion operation.

item.description:
###  **Purpose**:

The `wishlists` folder contains personal book lists linked to users. It's used to simulate preferences, goals, or gift registries.

###  **Data Structure**:

Wishlist objects have:

- `id`: Unique identifier.
    
- `name`: Wishlist title (auto-generated or custom).
    
- `books`: An array of book IDs.
    
- `createdAt`, `updatedAt`: Metadata.
    

###  **Relationships**:

- Each `user` has a `wishlistId`.
    
- Each wishlist contains `book` references by ID.
    

###  **Special Notes**:

- Book list is flat (not nested with book details).
    
- Adding/removing books only modifies the `books` array.
    
- `GET /wishlists/:id/books` can return full book objects for display.
